content.description: Suppose that the function f has a continuous second derivative for all x, and that f(0) = 2, f'(0) = -3,and f''(0) = 0. Let g be a function whose derivative is given by g'(x) = e-2x (3f(x) + 2f'(x)) for all x.
content.question: Show that g''(x) = e-2x(-6f(x) - f'(x) + 2f''(x)). Does g have a local maximum at x = 0? Justify your answer.

frqParts.text: Show that g''(x) = e-2x(-6f(x) - f'(x) + 2f''(x)). Does g have a local maximum at x = 0? Justify your answer.

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
